# Peak Clusters Report

## Cluster 0_0

[*assistant*:
Peak cluster 0_0 captures the chromatin program that turns on when neural progenitors begin to exit the cell-cycle and differentiate into functionally mature neurons.

1. Temporal dynamics  
   • Accessibility is modest at gastrulation/early somitogenesis (0–5 somites) and rises steeply from 10 somites onward, peaking at 20–30 somites (≈18–24 hpf).  
   • The progressive gain strongly parallels the appearance of electrical- and synapse-related transcripts (syn1, syt1a, sv2ca, cacna1bb, scn3b, nrxn2a/3b, tenm2, dscaml1).

2. Cell-type specificity  
   Highest accessibility is seen in:  
   • Differentiating neurons of the brain/spinal cord (largest signal, >10-fold above baseline by 20 somites).  
   • Enteric neurons (neural-crest derived) – early high signal (5–15 somites) that also plateaus at late stages.  
   • More modest enrichment in neural-crest pools and nascent presomitic mesoderm (PSM 30 somites), consistent with transient neurogenic competence there.  
   Non-neural tissues (muscle, endoderm, epidermis, heart, etc.) remain at baseline (~1).

3. Regulatory programme inferred  
   Gene and motif content point to a broad neuronal maturation module:  
   • Axon guidance / cell-adhesion: cntn3b/5, cntnap5a/l, dscaml1, pcdh15b, tenm2.  
   • Synaptic vesicle & neurotransmission: syn1, syt1a, sv2ca, cplx2l, rgs6, grin2bb.  
   • Ion-channel specification: cacna1bb, kcnh5a, kcnk10b, scn3b, abcc8.  
   • Activity-dependent plasticity / circadian components: nrg1, clock/ror/creb motifs.  
   • Thus the cluster marks the switch from progenitor to electrically active neuron and helps install regional (HOX/PAX/IRX) and lineage (SOX/NEUROD) identities.

4. Key transcription-factor drivers (motif enrichment + factor list)  
   • Pro-neuronal bHLH: NeuroD1/2/4/6, Atoh1/7, Olig2 – turn on neuronal gene battery.  
   • SOX family (SOX4/11/6/9, SOX10/21) – maintain neurogenic competence and aid differentiation.  
   • MEF2 (mef2ca/aa/ab) – synapse maturation and activity-dependent genes.  
   • RFX & NFAT motifs – ciliogenesis and Ca²⁺/activity-responsive programs in maturing neurons.  
   • HOX / PAX / IRX sets – impart anterior-posterior and regional neuronal identity.  
   • CREB/ATF/Jun–BATF (AP-1) and nuclear receptors (ROR/NR2F/NR1D) – underpin activity, circadian and metabolic coupling.

In summary, peak cluster 0_0 represents the chromatin signature of late neurogenesis and neuronal maturation, becoming most accessible during early organogenesis and predominantly in differentiating central and peripheral neurons, driven by SOX-, bHLH-, MEF2-, and region-specific HOX/PAX/IRX transcription factors.
]

## Cluster 0_1

[*assistant*:
Peak-cluster 0_1 represents a pan-neuronal enhancer module that switches on when progenitors leave the cell cycle and begin terminal differentiation.

1. Temporal dynamics  
   • Accessibility rises sharply from the 0- to 5-somite stage, peaks between 10–20 somites (≈14-19 hpf) and remains high through 24 hpf in most neuronal compartments.  
   • Enteric neurons show an early spike (0–20 somites) followed by a drop at 30 somites, indicating that this program is used transiently during early PNS maturation.

2. Cell-type specificity (highest accessibility)  
   • Differentiating neurons (CNS) – strongest signal at every sampled stage.  
   • Enteric neurons – very high at 5–20 somites.  
   • Additional but lower enrichment in hindbrain, spinal cord, neural crest–derived neurons, midbrain–hindbrain boundary and endocrine-pancreas neuro‐endocrine cells.  
   (Most non-neural lineages remain at baseline ~2, underscoring neuron-specific activity.)

3. Regulatory programme inferred  
   Associated genes are almost exclusively neuronal: axon guidance/extension (UNC5C, TRIM67, BRSK2, LRRc4c, ROBO-like SDK1), synaptic vesicle and release machinery (SNAP25b, SV2, SYT9a, CPLX2), ion-channels/receptors (CACNA2D3/4, GRIA3b, GRID2, GABRB4, RYR3, NTRK1), RNA-binding/ splicing factors (RBFOX1/3), cytoskeleton (MYO16, MYO3A), and neuro-endocrine markers (CHGA, TRPM5).  
   Together they mark the transition from post-mitotic neuroblasts to electrically active, synaptically connected neurons; i.e. axon outgrowth, synaptogenesis and acquisition of neurotransmission competence.

4. Key transcription-factor drivers (motif enrichment + gene set)  
   • SOX family (Sox2/3/11/4/21) – maintains neurogenic competence and initiates differentiation.  
   • Proneural / bHLH factors (NeuroD1/4/6, Atoh1, Olig2, Ascl1) – drive neuronal fate and neurite extension.  
   • PAX6, ONECUT (Onecut1/2/3), LHX & DLX homeodomain factors – pattern-specific neuronal subtype identity.  
   • HOX, NKX, and PBX/MEIS – rostro-caudal positional codes, especially evident in spinal and hindbrain neurons.  
   • NFI (NFIX/NFIA) & NFI-related CTF motifs – promote maturation and gliogenesis timing.  
   • MEF2 & ROR/NR2F nuclear receptors – activity-dependent and circadian neuronal gene programmes.  
   • FOXP/FOXD/FoxG motifs point to FOXP1/2 and FOXG1 inputs important for neuronal circuit assembly.  

In summary, cluster 0_1 encodes regulatory regions that activate a conserved neuronal maturation program, peaking during mid-somitogenesis and most prominent in differentiating central and enteric neurons, orchestrated by SOX, proneural bHLH, PAX/ONECUT/LHX homeoproteins and MEF2/Nuclear-receptor modules.
]

## Cluster 1_0

[*assistant*:
Peak cluster 1_0 captures a broad “late-somitogenesis differentiation” programme.

1. Temporal dynamics  
• Accessibility is modest and fairly uniform from 0- to 15-somite stages but rises sharply between 20- and 30-somites (≈ 22–24 hpf).  
• The increase is most obvious in 30-somite pseudobulks (e.g. Presomitic Mesoderm = 4.2 × mean, differentiating-neurons ≈ 1.5 ×, endocrine pancreas ≈ 1.6 ×).

2. Cell-type specificity (highest accessibility)  
• Presomitic & somitic mesoderm → fast/slow muscle precursors, lateral-plate mesoderm.  
• Hindbrain & spinal cord neurons (differentiating-neurons, floor-plate, neural floor plate).  
• Cranio-facial/arch mesenchyme and optic cup derivatives show local spikes.  
Overall the cluster is most open in mesoderm-derived tissues that are segmenting or beginning terminal myogenic / connective-tissue programmes, with parallel but weaker activation in late neuro-ectoderm.

3. Regulatory programme inferred from associated genes  
• Very large set enriched for:  
  – Extracellular-matrix & cell-adhesion (multiple collagens, integrins, ADAM/ADAMTS, Tnc, Fbn2).  
  – Axon guidance / synaptic components (Cntn, Cdh, Nrxn, Grin, Gabbr, Slc12a5, Syt).  
  – Muscle contractile & Ca²⁺-handling genes (Myh11, Ryr1/2/3, Pvalb, Myl, Mef2 targets).  
  – Patterning factors (many Hox, Pbx, Meis, Barx, Dlx, Irx transcripts).  
These signatures point to late morphogenesis events: somite maturation into muscle/connective tissue, establishment of A-P (Hox) identity and wiring of nascent neural circuits.

4. Key transcription-factor motifs enriched  
(homeobox- and differentiation-driving factors dominate)  
• HOX paralogs (Hoxb1/2/3/4/5, Hoxc8/9/10/11/13, Hoxd9/10/11/12/13) – confer segmental A-P identity.  
• PBX / MEIS / PKNOX TALE cofactors – cooperative partners that sharpen Hox specificity.  
• DLX, BARX, IRX, PAX3/7 – regulators of cranio-facial mesenchyme, neural crest and muscle segment borders.  
• SOX (Sox5/9/10/11) & FOX (Foxd3/1/2, Foxi, Foxk) – maintain neural-crest, mesodermal and ectodermal programmes.  
• MEF2 & SRF motifs – activate muscle structural genes during myofibre differentiation.  
• GATA and RFX/Nuclear-receptor motifs (NR2F/COUP, RAR/RXR) – typical of late tissue maturation and ECM production.

Summary  
Cluster 1_0 marks regulatory regions that switch on late in somitogenesis, predominantly in presomitic/somitic mesoderm and late neuro-ectoderm, to drive Hox-guided patterning, extracellular-matrix remodelling and terminal differentiation of muscle and neural lineages. The motif landscape points to a HOX–PBX/MEIS–SOX/FOX regulatory hub, with MEF2/SRF fine-tuning contractile gene expression once myogenesis commences.
]

## Cluster 1_1

[*assistant*:
Peak-cluster 1_1 marks regulatory DNA that “switches on” as the embryo leaves segmentation and begins organ formation.

1. Temporal dynamics  
   • Accessibility is modest and almost uniform at 0–10 somites (10–16 hpf) but rises steadily thereafter, reaching its maximum at 20–30 somite stages (≈20–24 hpf).  
   • Highest values are seen in the 30-somite samples, indicating that the elements become most active during early organogenesis rather than during gastrulation/early segmentation.

2. Cell-type specificity  
   Highest accessibility is confined to endoderm-derived tissues and their immediate derivatives:  
   • bulk “endoderm” pseudobulk (2.3-fold at 30 somites – cluster maximum)  
   • endocrine-pancreas lineage (1.55-fold)  
   • heart myocardium and fast muscle show intermediate signal; neuromesodermal progenitors, tail-bud, ectodermal neural tissues and epidermis are low or absent.  
   → The cluster therefore reports an endoderm/visceral organ enhancer set with some spread into closely related mesodermal organs (heart).

3. Predicted regulatory programme / biology  
   • Gene-body and expression links point to classical endoderm / gut / pancreas genes (pdx1, gata4/5/6, hnf4a/g, foxa/b/f family, rfx6, tal1, gata2/3, etc.) as well as metabolic and secretory genes (abca/abcb transporters, apoa/p, mucs, digestive enzymes).  
   • GO/process interpretation: specification and epithelial maturation of fore-/mid-gut, initiation of pancreatic endocrine programme, onset of organ-specific metabolism and extracellular-matrix re-organisation.  
   • Retinoic-acid / nuclear-receptor signatures (RAR/RXR, HNF4, PPAR) and pioneer-factor motifs (FOXA, GATA) suggest chromatin opening in response to RA signalling that licenses gut-tube and pancreatic enhancers.

4. Key transcription-factor drivers (motif enrichment + linked TF genes)  
   • Pioneer / opener: FOXA1/2/3, FOXC/F, FOXK (strong FOX motif block).  
   • Endoderm master regulators: GATA4/5/6, SOX17/32.  
   • Pancreas-specific: PDX1, RFX6, HNF1B, ONECUT1/2/3.  
   • Nuclear-receptor / RA axis: RARA/RARG, RXRα/β, HNF4A/G, NR5A1/2, PPARA/AB/G.  
   • Additional supporting factors: CEBP family, KLFs, MEF2 (heart overlap), and HOX/MEIS-PBX complexes reflecting anterior–posterior gut patterning.

In summary, cluster 1_1 represents a late-acting endoderm enhancer module that opens broadly across gut endoderm and peaks in the nascent pancreas, heart and other visceral organs at 20–30 somites, driven by a FOXA/GATA/PDX1/RA-receptor centred transcriptional circuit that orchestrates early organogenesis and metabolic maturation of internal organs.
]

## Cluster 1_2

[*assistant*:
Peak cluster 1_2 in a nutshell

1. Temporal dynamics  
   • Accessibility is modest at 0–5-somite stages (10–12 hpf) but rises steadily afterwards, reaching its maximum at 20–30-somites (≈20–24 hpf).  
   • This late-gastrula → early-organogenesis increase is seen in virtually every lineage that shows enrichment (see below), indicating that the elements in this cluster are switched on as the trunk and tail rapidly elongate and differentiate.

2. Cell-type specificity (top quartile of accessibility)  
   • Posterior paraxial mesoderm: presomitic mesoderm (PSM) and forming somites (PSM_30 s: 4.3; somites_30 s ≈ 4–5).  
   • Neuro-mesodermal progenitors (NMPs) and tail-bud.  
   • Spinal cord / hind-brain neurons and differentiating neurons (values > 2.5–3 at 15–30 somites).  
   • Neural-crest derivatives – especially enteric, peripheral and optic-cup lineages (enteric-neurons_15 s 3.2; optic-cup 10–30 s 2.8–3.1).  
   • Pigment/melanocyte precursors show moderate but consistent accessibility (mitfa-positive lineages).  
   ⇒ The pattern is “trunk & tail”-biased and shared between mesodermal (somitic) and neural/neural-crest populations.

3. Biological programme represented  
   Gene correlations point to processes required for trunk patterning, axial elongation and peripheral-nervous-system assembly:  
   • Somitogenesis & myogenesis: pdgfra, tcf12, runx3, myl9, myo10l3, mark2a, mstn-related genes.  
   • Axon guidance / sensory neuron maturation: unc5c, unc5a, dcc, epha/b genes, piezo2, ryr2, cntn3b, cntnap5, lrttm4, zeb2a.  
   • Neural-crest specification & migration: sox10, prdm1b, zeb2a, ednraa, mitfa, tfec.  
   • A-P patterning: many posterior HOX motifs enriched, plus nr2f2, nr6a1/caudal-like cdx signatures.  
   • Circadian / metabolic maturation hints (arntl1b, per2, srebf1/2, fut8a) are typical of late-differentiating trunk tissues.

4. Key transcription-factor drivers (top enriched motif families)  
   • Posterior HOX (Hox9-13) & CDX – set up trunk positional identity.  
   • SOX family (Sox10/9/5/4/21) – neural crest and neuro-mesodermal progenitors.  
   • PAX3/7 & DLX/IRX clusters – border-domain and neural-crest enhancers.  
   • FOX (Foxd3/Foxi/Foxc) – neural-crest and mesodermal axial elongation.  
   • RUNX3, NR2F2/COUP-TF, NR4A nuclear receptors – maturation of spinal sensory neurons & mesoderm.  
   • MITF/TFEC & BHLH (NeuroD/ATOH) – pigment cell and neuronal differentiation, respectively.  

Interpretation  
Peak cluster 1_2 contains enhancers that become progressively accessible as the zebrafish trunk and tail form.  They are shared by posterior paraxial mesoderm, neuro-mesodermal progenitors, spinal cord / hind-brain neurons and neural-crest derivatives.  The regulatory code combines HOX-CDX positional cues with SOX/FOX/PAX-mediated neural-crest and mesoderm programmes, driving late somitogenesis, neurogenesis and peripheral-nervous-system differentiation during 20–24 hpf.
]

## Cluster 1_3

[*assistant*:
Peak cluster 1_3 – concise interpretation  

1. Temporal dynamics  
   • Accessibility is already high at the earliest stage we profiled (0-somite / 10 hpf) and rises further, peaking between 10- and 20-somites (≈13–19 hpf).  
   • Accessibility collapses by 30-somites (≈24 hpf), indicating that these elements are used during early, not late, organogenesis.

2. Cell-type specificity  
   • By far the highest signals occur in the superficial ectoderm:  
     – epidermis_0 – 20 somites = 8–11 (other tissues are ≤ 4).  
   • Moderate accessibility (≈3–4) is seen in enteric-neuron and somite pseudobulks, but this is secondary.  
   ⇒ Cluster 1_3 marks regulatory DNA that is specific to the early epidermis/periderm.

3. Regulatory programme implied  
   Gene set is enriched for:  
   • Epidermal barrier / periderm structural genes – tp63, krt92, lamc2/3, itga3/6/v, claudins (tjp2b), tgm2b, numerous collagens (col4a3/4, col11a1, col12a1), vcanb, smoc2, adamts proteases, ECM organizers (laminin, fibronectin-like).  
   • Cell-junction & polarity factors – pard3bb, patj, ctnna2, ctnnd1/2, pkp3, cadherin 24, claudins.  
   • Signalling molecules important for surface ectoderm (jag1a/b, wnt6b, pdgfc, epgn).  
   Biological processes therefore point to epithelial sheet formation, adhesion and extracellular-matrix remodelling that build the protective skin/periderm during gastrulation–segmentation.

4. Likely driver transcription factors  
   Motif enrichment and gene co-expression point to the canonical epidermal/periderm network:  
   • AP-2 family (TFAP2A/C/D) – highest positive motif Z-scores (M00111-113); Tfap2c gene present.  
   • p63 (tp63 gene in cluster, p53-family motif enriched – M051/x).  
   • Grainyhead‐like factors (grhl1/2) – GRHL motif group (row 44) enriched.  
   • IRF6 / IRF family – motifs enriched (row 21) and irf6 gene in TF list; cooperate with p63 in periderm.  
   • KLF/Sp and C/EBP family motifs (rows 86, 102) – epidermal differentiation/cohesion.  
   • GATA3/6 and TEAD/TA (rows 18, 82) – reinforce epithelial identity.  

Together these data argue that peak-cluster 1_3 comprises early-opening enhancers used by the periderm / surface epidermis during gastrulation–early segmentation, driven by an AP-2–p63–GRHL–IRF6 transcriptional module that activates genes for cell-adhesion, ECM deposition and epithelial barrier formation.
]

## Cluster 1_4

[*assistant*:
Peak-cluster 1_4 marks a mesoderm-derived, haemo-vascular transcriptional module.

1. Temporal dynamics  
   • Accessibility is already above background at the 0–5-somite stages, rises sharply at 10–15 somites and reaches its maximum at 20–30 somites (note 8.5-fold signal in “hematopoietic / vasculature 30 somites” and 5.7-fold in “PSM 30 somites”).  
   • This timing coincides with the transition from vasculogenic specification (≈12–14 hpf) to active sprouting and maturation of the embryonic circulation (18–24 hpf).

2. Cell-type specificity  
   Highest accessibility is seen in:  
   • Hematopoietic / vascular endothelium and hemangioblast clusters (4–8 log₂-units).  
   • Late presomitic/somite mesoderm (PSM 30 somites, somite derivatives), reflecting their shared mesodermal origin.  
   Moderate accessibility is observed in endoderm and fast-muscle but is clearly secondary to the vascular signal.

3. Underlying regulatory programme  
   Associated gene set is enriched for canonical endothelial / angiogenic / hemogenic regulators and effectors:  
   • Endothelial identity & sprouting – fli1a, erg/etv genes, flt4 (Vegfr3), esama/esamb, stab2, fgd5a, rock1, tlk1, tln1, cxcr3, robo1.  
   • Vascular ECM & lumen formation – fbn2a, hmcn1, fut8a, vwa8, stab2.  
   • Hematopoietic/immune priming – gata2/3, ikzf2, tal1-interactors (lcp2a, def6b), cd22, runx genes.  
   • Cell-cycle/proliferation components (E2F/Kdm2b module) consistent with rapid endothelial expansion.  
   Together these peaks describe the cis-regulatory landscape that drives vasculogenesis, early angiogenesis and emergence of hemogenic endothelium.

4. Key transcription-factor drivers (motif enrichment & gene presence)  
   • ETS family: Fli1/Elf/Etv/Erg motifs dominate – master switches for endothelial fate.  
   • FOX factors: Foxc1/2, Foxf1/2, Foxo1 – cooperate with ETS to activate vascular gene batteries.  
   • COUP-TF / NR2F (nr2f1/2/6) – venous/lymphatic endothelial specification.  
   • GATA2/6 and RUNX1/2/3 – hematopoietic competence of the endothelium.  
   • KLF2/6/9 and E2F1/2/3 – shear-responsive endothelial maintenance and proliferation.  
   • Supporting factors: MEF2C/CB (vascular maturation), TFCP2/TFEB/TFEC (endothelial metabolism).

In summary, peak-cluster 1_4 captures the enhancer repertoire that becomes progressively accessible during somitogenesis to establish and expand the embryonic vascular and hemogenic endothelial lineages, driven chiefly by an ETS-FOX-COUP-TF core transcriptional circuit.
]

## Cluster 1_5

[*assistant*:
Interpretation of peak-cluster 1 _5  

1. Temporal dynamics  
• Accessibility rises steadily across the somitogenesis series and reaches a clear maximum at 20- to 30-somite stages (≈ 22–24 hpf).  
• Early gastrula/0-somite samples show only moderate signal; activity continues to grow rather than switching off, arguing for a role late in axis extension and early organogenesis rather than an early, transient burst.

2. Cell-type specificity  
Highest chromatin openness is seen in tissues that derive from the posterior paraxial mesoderm:  
  • Presomitic mesoderm (PSM), especially PSM_30-somites (13.8 – the global peak)  
  • Newly formed somites and fast-muscle myoblasts  
  • Neuromesodermal progenitors (tail-bud) show intermediate signal, consistent with their PSM bias  
Accessibility is low in neural, endodermal, epidermal and most differentiated neuronal populations, indicating the cluster is largely mesoderm-restricted.

3. Regulatory programme represented  
Gene bodies and co-expressed transcripts linked to the peaks are heavily enriched for:  
  • Hox paralog groups (hoxa1-13, hoxb/c/d clusters) – posterior axial patterning  
  • Segmentation/mesoderm factors: mespaa/mespab, tbx6/tbx16, tbx3, tbx18, tbx24, cdx1b/cdx4  
  • Early myogenic and extracellular-matrix genes (myhz2, lama1, loxl, col5a1/3, mmp11, adamts2/3)  
  • Retinoic-acid and RA-metabolism components (rarga/b, aldh1a2, cyp26 family)  
Together these point to enhancers that coordinate AP identity, segmentation and the first wave of myogenic differentiation in the trunk/tail.

4. Key transcription-factor drivers (motif enrichment + gene presence)  
• Hox/Cdx code – Hoxa/b/c & Cdx1b/4 motifs dominate, matching the extensive Hox gene list.  
• T-box factors – Tbx6, Tbx16 and Tbx3 motifs; their RNAs are accessible and expressed in PSM/somites.  
• Fox family (Foxc1/2, Foxf1/2, Foxi, Foxj1) – classic regulators of paraxial mesoderm and somite epithelialisation.  
• RA-receptors (Rarg, Rxr, Rorb) – motifs and cognate genes enriched, consistent with RA-mediated Hox activation during trunk patterning.  
• MEF2 and MRF motifs appear but at lower accessibility, fitting the onset of myogenic commitment in older somites.

Summary  
Peak-cluster 1 _5 marks a regulatory module that switches on progressively during somitogenesis in posterior paraxial mesoderm, controlling Hox-driven axial identity, segmentation genes (Mesp/Tbx/Cdx) and the earliest myogenic/ECM programmes that shape the trunk and tail of the zebrafish embryo.
]

## Cluster 1_6

[*assistant*:
Peak-cluster 1_6 marks the “late-neuronal” chromatin programme

1. Temporal dynamics  
   • Accessibility is low at gastrulation/early somitogenesis (0-10 somites ≈10–14 hpf), rises steadily, and peaks at 25–30 somites (~22-24 hpf).  
   • The sharp jump in differentiating-neurons from 2.7 (0 s) to 11.9 (30 s) and in most neuronal compartments (hindbrain, spinal cord, enteric- and optic-neurons) shows that the cluster switches on during the transition from neurogenesis to early circuit assembly.

2. Cell-type specificity (highest accessibility)  
   • Differentiating-neurons (all regional identities)  
   • Mature neuronal derivatives – spinal cord, hind-/mid-brain, optic cup, enteric and neural-crest neurons  
   • Moderate in other neuroectoderm-derived tissues (floor plate, neural crest) and late presomitic mesoderm, but low/absent in endoderm, epidermis or early mesoderm.  
   → The pattern is therefore pan-neuronal rather than lineage-restricted.

3. Regulatory programme inferred from linked genes  
   The 260 + associated genes are strongly enriched for neuronal maturation functions:  
   • Synaptic components & neurotransmission CACNA1/2/4, SCN8A, GRIA3, GRIK2, GLRA4, SLC18A3, RYR3, NPAS3, PRKG1, CAMK1D  
   • Axon guidance / adhesion LRRTM4, KIRREL3, NLGN4, PCDH clusters, CADM1, L1CAM, PLXNA3, EPHA7/B2  
   • Vesicle release RIMS2, CADPS, STXBP5, RPH3A  
   • Neuronal cytoskeleton & signalling MAP1AB, ANK3, DISC1, TRIM67, MTUS, MYO16, DIAPH3  
   • ECM remodelling for neurite outgrowth ADAMTS7, FBLN2, MMP24, SPARC-family, PGFB  
   GO/pathway enrichment (not shown) invariably points to “axonogenesis”, “chemical synaptic transmission”, “glutamatergic signalling” and “membrane depolarisation”.  
   → Cluster 1_6 therefore represents the chromatin module that licenses terminal differentiation and synaptogenesis of embryonic neurons.

4. Likely driver transcription factors (motif enrichment + gene list)  
   Motifs with highest z-scores map to four TF families that are all expressed in the linked RNA data:  

   • Proneural / bHLH NEUROD1/4, ATOH7, NEUROG2, OLIG2 (motif groups 15, 42) – activate neuronal differentiation genes.  
   • SOX-C/SOX-D SOX4/11/12, SOX5/6, SOX21 (groups 1, 35, 61) – maintain neuronal identity and open chromatin.  
   • TALE–homeobox / PBX-MEIS-HOX (groups 22, 25, 72) – regional patterning and axon-pathway wiring (PBX1/3/4, MEIS1/2, multiple HOX paralogues).  
   • RFX & RFX-like (group 58) – known regulators of late neuronal gene batteries including axon extension and ciliary genes (RFX3/4/6).  

   Supporting factors: FOXP1/2/4, NPAS3, KDM2B (present in gene list) and E2F-family motifs (group 6/13) that probably reflect a final wave of cell-cycle exit.

Summary  
Peak-cluster 1_6 is a pan-neuronal, late-developmental chromatin module that opens as neurons exit the cell cycle and begin axon outgrowth and synapse formation (20–24 hpf). It is most accessible in differentiating and newly born neurons throughout the CNS and PNS and is driven by a combination of proneural bHLH, SOX, PBX/MEIS/HOX and RFX transcription factors orchestrating neuronal maturation and connectivity.
]

## Cluster 1_7

[*assistant*:
Peak-cluster 1_7 represents the constitutively open “core-promoter / housekeeping” compartment of the zebrafish embryo.

1. Temporal dynamics  
   • Accessibility is already high at the first sampled stage (10 hpf; 0-somites) and remains uniformly high through 24 hpf (30-somites).  
   • Only a modest, gradual rise (≈ +10–15 %) is seen toward the end of somitogenesis (e.g. PSM-30 somites 5.2 vs ~2.5–3.0 elsewhere), indicating that these regions are active throughout but gain a little more accessibility as global transcription ramps up.

2. Cell-type specificity  
   • Virtually every pseudobulk shows strong accessibility (2–3 on the internal scale).  
   • No lineage shows exclusive enrichment; minor dips occur in very early fast-muscle and tail-bud pseudobulks, but accessibility quickly matches the embryo‐wide level.  
   • Conclusion: the cluster is cell-type universal rather than lineage-restricted.

3. Regulatory program / biological function  
   • The peaks map to, or correlate with, >6 000 genes that span metabolism, cell-cycle, translation, cytoskeleton, signalling and ubiquitous chromatin regulators—classical housekeeping sets.  
   • GO/KEGG Enrichment (from the gene catalogue) is dominated by:  
     – RNA processing / translation initiation  
     – Core metabolic pathways (glycolysis, TCA, lipid metabolism)  
     – DNA replication and repair  
     – Cytoskeleton and vesicle trafficking  
   • Together with the uniform accessibility, this indicates that cluster 1_7 comprises promoters (and some first introns/5′UTRs) required for basal cellular activity across all embryonic cells.

4. Key transcription-factor drivers  
   • Motif landscape is broad but heavily enriched for factors that bind core promoters or are pioneer/ubiquitous:  
     – General promoter factors: NF-Y, SP1/SP2/SP3, KLF family, YY1, CREB/ATF, ETS (GABP/ELF/ELK/Fli), NRF-1/2, E2F + TFDP.  
     – Pioneer / architectural factors: CTCF, CXXC/KDM2, FOX(K/F/O), SOX (1/2/3/19), BACH/NFE2L, NRF (NR1/2 family).  
     – Basal transcription machinery: TBP/TBP-like (TBPL2), TFII-I (GTF2I), TFCP2.  
   • None of these are lineage-defining; they act collectively to keep promoters nucleosome-free and competent for transcription.

In summary, peak-cluster 1_7 is a genome-wide set of promoter-proximal elements that are constitutively accessible in virtually all cells from gastrulation through early organogenesis, supporting ubiquitous housekeeping gene expression rather than a lineage-specific developmental program.
]

## Cluster 1_8

[*assistant*:
Peak-cluster 1_8 marks the switch from generic trunk mesoderm to the highly patterned, posterior presomitic/somitic mesoderm that appears at the end of our sampling window.

1. Temporal dynamics  
   • Accessibility is roughly baseline (≈1.3–1.6 a.u.) from gastrula through 20-somite stage, then jumps >20-fold at 30-somites (≈24 hpf).  
   • Thus the cluster is principally activated during the last stage assayed, coincident with late somitogenesis and tail elongation.

Highly enriched or co-expressed TF families that fit the temporal / cell-type pattern:

## Cluster 5_0

[*assistant*:
Peak-cluster 5_0 marks a classical “epithelial/secretory module” that turns on mid-somitogenesis and is shared by surface ectoderm–derived epithelia and endodermal secretory tissues.

1. Temporal dynamics  
   • Accessibility is already detectable at 0–5-somites, but rises sharply between 10- and 15-somites (≈14–18 hpf), then gradually decreases by 30-somites (≈24 hpf).  
   • The peak therefore coincides with early organogenesis, when epithelia polarise and the first endocrine pancreatic cells mature.

2. Cell-type specificity (highest pseudobulk values)  
   • Hatching-gland/​periderm (56–89 a.u.; strongest signal).  
   • Endocrine-pancreas (38–57 a.u.).  
   • Surface epidermis (34–46 a.u.).  
   • Maturing endoderm and gut epithelium also show moderate accessibility, whereas mesodermal or neural lineages are low.

3. Regulatory programme inferred from associated genes  
   The gene set is enriched for:
   • Epithelial junction / polarity components – epcam, cldn7b/​cldnb, ocln/​oclnb, pard3ba, rab25, alcama, cx28.8.  
   • Cytoskeleton & adhesion – flnb, enah, shroom3, flrt2, itpr1/2, capn family.  
   • Secretory and metabolic factors – abca3b, atp8b1, fabp2, ugt8, ppargc1a, gfpt2.

   • FOX family (Foxi3a/b, Foxa1/3, Foxd1/3, Foxl1, FOXK2) – pioneers of epithelial and endodermal enhancers.  
   • GATA factors (Gata4/5/6, Gata3) – drive endoderm- and ectoderm-derived epithelial genes.  
   • GRHL/TFCP2 & KLF family (Grhl2b, Tfcp2, Klf4/5/17) – establish tight-junction gene expression.  
   • PDX1 / Onecut / HNF (Pdx1, Onecut1/2/3, Hnf4a/g) – endocrine-pancreas differentiation.  
   • SOX & Ovol/​Otx auxiliary motifs – maintain epithelial identity.  
   • NR5A/PPAR/Retinoid-receptor motifs – link to lipid-handling and secretory maturation.

In summary, cluster 5_0 comprises enhancers that switch on during mid-somitogenesis in hatching-gland, epidermal and endocrine-pancreatic epithelia, orchestrated principally by FOX and GATA factors together with epithelial-maintenance TFs (GRHL/KLF/TFCP2) and pancreas-specific drivers (PDX1-Onecut-HNF).

## Cluster 5_1

Peak-cluster 5_1 captures a short-lived, “early‐segmentation” chromatin programme that is shared by several nascent trunk lineages.

   • Accessibility is maximal at the 0–5-somite stages (≈10–13 hpf) and falls steeply thereafter (10 som ≈14 hpf; almost baseline by 25–30 som).

   Motif enrichment (highest z-scores) and TF-name overlap highlight:  
   • Hox–Pbx/Meis axis (motifs M00111-114) – master regulators of axial identity.  
   • Sox family (sox5/9/10/19, sox2/3) – neural-crest & neuro-ectoderm competence.  
   • Fox factors (foxa/foxd/foxf) – mesendoderm and epithelial remodelling.  
   • Pax3/7, Pax6 – epidermal/neural crest & early neurogenesis.  
   • Nkx & Tbx (nkx2.x, tbx20/5) – mesoderm and cardiac/somite polarity.  
   • Mef2 / MyoD – initiating skeletal-muscle gene expression.  
   • Runx, Gata, Irx/Lhx/Barhl families – lineage-specific controllers for enteric neurons and cranial structures.  
   • E2F/FOX M1 – brief proliferation burst accompanying early fate decisions.

## Cluster 5_2

[*assistant*:
Peak-cluster 5_2 captures an “early surface-ectoderm / periderm” programme that switches on as soon as the embryo starts making somites and is largely shut down by the end of the first day.

1. Temporal dynamics  
• Accessibility is already high at 0-somite stage (10 hpf), climbs to a maximum at 10--15 somites (~15-19 hpf; epidermis 46-47 a.u.), and falls sharply by 30 somites (~24 hpf).  
→ The peaks therefore mark a transient window spanning gastrulation to mid-segmentation when the periderm and nascent epidermis are being specified and spread.

2. Cell-type specificity  
• Highest signals: epidermis / surface ectoderm (top values 41-47).  
• Secondary but distinctly lower signal: paraxial mesoderm derivatives (somites, fast-muscle, PSM, NMPs) – these tissues lie immediately beneath the periderm and share some epithelial programmes.  
• Very low in neuro‐ectoderm, endoderm, blood/vasculature or internal organs.  
→ Cluster 5_2 is strongly biased to the outer epithelial sheet.

3. Regulatory programme inferred  
Associated genes are enriched for:  
• Epithelial barrier & cytoskeleton: keratin regulators (tp63), junction/adhesion components (adamts2/10, col1/2/7/18, lama1, itga3, itgb6, tns1).  
• Extracellular-matrix remodelling and basement-membrane deposition (mmp9, hmcn1, fbn2b, postnb, vcana).  
• BMP / TGFβ / Wnt cues that specify non-neural ectoderm (bmp2b/3/4, bmpr1ab/2b, wnt10a, tgfb1a, tgfbr3).  
• Grainyhead and p63 targets (grhl1, tp63, claudin-like genes) that drive periderm maturation.  
Functional theme: assembly and expansion of the embryonic periderm / epidermis and its underlying basal lamina during body elongation.

4. Likely driver transcription factors  
Motif enrichment together with expressed TFs points to:  
• TP63 – master regulator of stratified epithelia; its gene and binding motif are present.  
• GRHL family (Grhl1) – essential for periderm sealing.  
• GATA3 – promotes ectodermal and epidermal gene sets.  
• TEAD / Hippo (Tead3b) – cooperates with p63 in epithelial growth.  
• AP-1 (Fos/Jun, Batf) and KLF factors (Klf17/9/4) – generic epithelial and wound-response enhancers.  
• IRF6/ARNT‐family motifs – known periderm regulators (cleft-lip/-palate genes).  
• FOX factors (Foxp1/4, Foxl1) – often cooperate with p63/Grhl in barrier formation.

Together, these data place peak-cluster 5_2 at the core of the transient transcriptional and chromatin programme that builds the zebrafish periderm / early epidermis during somite stages.

## Cluster 13_7

Peak-cluster 13_7 represents an “axial-mesoderm / notochord programme”

• Accessibility is already high at the earliest sample (0-somite, 10 hpf) and steadily falls thereafter.

Summary: the cluster is most active during gastrulation and early somitogenesis, i.e. while the notochord is being generated and patterned.

2. Cell-type specificity  
• Dominant signal: notochord (≈ 270-fold higher than background at 0-somites).  
• Sub-threshold yet above background in axial progenitors (NMPs), pre-somitic mesoderm and, later, a subset of neural crest / enteric neurons.  
Thus the peaks are chiefly notochord-specific with a shallow footprint in closely related axial lineages.

3. Likely biological processes  
Gene set and GO inspection point to—  
• Mid-line morphogenesis & planar-cell-polarity: FAT4, CDH11, Wnt4, Cdh11, Agrn, Tenm2.  
• ECM & basement-membrane assembly required for the notochord sheath (Agrn, Col-related genes).  
• Guidance/axon-sorting molecules that the notochord supplies to adjacent neuroepithelium (Cntn4, Nrxn2, Pcdh15, Plxna2/b, Sema3f).  
• Cell-cycle & chromatin genes (E2F-targets) consistent with the rapid expansion of axial progenitors.  
Overall, the cluster captures regulatory DNA driving formation of the notochord, its extracellular sheath, and its signalling interface with overlying neural tissue.

4. Key transcription-factor drivers (motifs + expressed factors)  
Highly enriched motifs together with expression in the same cells pinpoint:  
• Brachyury/Ta (T-box) – canonical notochord master regulator; motif present and ta expressed in axial mesoderm.  
• Fox family (FoxA2, FoxD3, FoxC1/2, FoxF) – required for notochord differentiation and sheath gene activation.  
• Noto (homeobox) – mid-line identity gene; motif strongly enriched.  
• Hox & Lhx clusters – anterior-posterior patterning of the chord and its neural signalling domains.  
• E2F1/2/3/5/7/8 – reinforce the proliferative state of axial progenitors.

Taken together, peak-cluster 13_7 marks early notochord cis-regulatory elements activated by Brachyury and FOX factors to run an ECM/PCP/signalling programme that establishes and patterns the embryonic mid-line.

• Cytoskeleton / axon guidance – adamts9, srgap3, ssh2b, traf3ip1.

• SoxC family (Sox4/11) and SoxB (Sox2/3/19) – maintain neural competence and promote neurite growth.

## Cluster 13_17

[*assistant*:
Peak cluster 13_17 marks a set of regulatory elements that “switch on” late in somitogenesis and are almost exclusively opened in the emerging retina.

1. Temporal dynamics  
• Accessibility is low and flat (≈3–4 a.u.) from gastrulation through 20-somite stages, then rises sharply at 30 somites (≈24 hpf).  
• The jump is >70-fold in optic-cup nuclei (optic_cup_30 somites ≈ 270) and ~7-fold in the presomitic mesoderm (PSM_30 somites ≈ 26), indicating a late-somite/early-organogenesis activation.

2. Cell-type specificity  
Highest accessibility is seen in:  
• Optic cup / retinal neuroepithelium → dominant signal.  
• Minor but measurable opening in late PSM and maturing somites; virtually baseline in all other lineages.  
Thus the cluster is retina-biased, with weak spill-over to mesoderm that may reflect shared motif usage rather than function.

3. Regulatory programme inferred from linked genes  
Enriched gene set is packed with retina/neuronal differentiation factors and photoreceptor structural genes:  
• Eye-field/photoreceptor TFs: six7, rorb, crx, pitx2/3, otx1/2, barhl, pax6.  
• Synaptic and axon-guidance molecules: nrxn2/3, cntnap2a, ctnna2, dscama, agrn, grid2, cadpsa, bsnb.  
• Photoreceptor/RPE structural & disease genes: ush2a, vstm2a, smoc2, smyd1a, ush2a.  
• Neuro-transmission & signalling: gabrb1, glra1, tph2, ntrk1/3, oprk1.  
Together these point to a programme that drives terminal differentiation of retinal neurons—especially photoreceptors—and assembly of their synaptic machinery.

4. Key transcription-factor drivers (motifs highly enriched in the cluster)  
• SIX / sine-oculis family: Six6, Six7, Six3/4 – master regulators of photoreceptor gene batteries.  
• OTX/CRX homeobox group (Otx1/2, Crx, Dmbx1) – activate phototransduction genes.  
• PAX6 & related paired box factors – retinal progenitor competence.  
• Nuclear receptors linked to photoreceptor subtype choice: RORβ (rorb), NR2E3, RXRs/RARs.  
• Onecut (Oc1/2/3) & LHX/Barhl families – retinal interneuron lineage factors.  
• Maf/Nrl axis (mafab, nrl, mafk) – rod vs cone fate specification.  
The concurrence of these motifs with the gene set and optic-cup-restricted accessibility strongly argues that SIX–OTX/CRX–PAX6–ROR modules are the primary regulators opening this peak cluster.

Summary  
Peak cluster 13_17 is a retina-specific, late-somite enhancer set that becomes highly accessible as optic-cup cells exit the progenitor state and begin photoreceptor and retinal neuron differentiation. It is driven by SIX, OTX/CRX, PAX6 and nuclear-receptor TFs and coordinates expression of adhesion, synaptic and phototransduction genes necessary for functional retinal neuron development.

## Cluster 17_4

[*assistant*:
Peak-cluster 17_4 represents a large set of regulatory regions that are open in many – but not all – embryonic lineages.  Inspection of the pseudo-bulk accessibility, the linked genes and the enriched motifs points to a core programme that supports early “mesenchyme / endothelium / endoderm” morphogenesis, i.e. cell migration, extracellular–matrix production and initial vascular / organ priming.

   • Haemangioblast / nascent vasculature (3.6–4.0) and lateral-plate mesoderm.  
   • Early mesenchyme-like populations (pharyngeal arches, cranial mesenchyme), neural crest and differentiating neurons keep the loci open (≈3.1–3.6).  
   • Accessibility is clearly lower in late trunk mesoderm (NMP 30 som, PSM 30 som) and mature muscle, emphasising the mesenchymal / migratory bias.

   • Extracellular-matrix structural genes (Collagens I/II/IV/VI, Col12a1, Col21a1, etc.), integrins (Itga5/8/10, Itgb3), MMP/ADAM family proteases – pointing to ECM production & remodelling.

   • Endoderm/visceral organ priming genes (Pdx1, Sox17, Gata4/5/6).  
   Collectively this suggests that cluster 17_4 coordinates EMT-like transitions, cell migration, early vasculature assembly and endodermal organ budding during the 10–24 hpf window.

   Motif-enrichment plus factor mapping highlights four cooperative TF families that match the biology above:  
   • ETS factors (Etv2, Fli1, Erg, Elf1/2) – master regulators of endothelial/haemangioblast identity and ECM gene activation.

Gene content (adamts17, adamtsl3, bmp16, dnah7, cfap99, cadps2, rab26, rims1/3, syt9, piezo1/2, rock1/2, vegfab, wasl) and the GO terms these genes usually map to indicate a convergence on:

   • Accessibility is modest (≈2–3 a.u.) from 0- to 20-somite stages, spikes in the optic cup at 10 som (40 a.u.), and shows a dramatic surge at 30 som/24 hpf in epidermis (87 a.u.).  
   • The pattern suggests an early, transient role during eye morphogenesis followed by a major activation during late skin maturation.

2. Cell-type specificity (highest accessibility)  
   • Surface ectoderm / epidermis – strongest at 30 som.  
   • Optic cup epithelium – sharp peak at 10 som.  
   • Minor but consistent accessibility in other epithelial derivatives (endocrine pancreas, endoderm, hemangioblasts) but at background levels compared with epidermis/optic cup.

3. Likely regulated biological processes  
   • Epidermal terminal differentiation and barrier formation – presence of keratin-associated genes (e.g. krt-like collagens, cornification/ECM genes col6a3, col21a1, col4a6; adhesion genes cntn3, kirrel3; lipid-handling genes abcg1, mgat4/5).  
   • Epithelial morphogenesis and apical constriction (shroom2, syne1, rimbp2).  
   • Eye-field/optic cup patterning (wnt9a, nrg1, pax-/rx-associated factors in motif list).  
   • General extracellular-matrix remodelling and glycosylation required for epithelial sheet stability.

4. Key transcription-factor drivers (motifs enriched in this cluster)  
   • p63/TP73 – master regulator of epidermal stratification (motif set 51).  
   • TFAP2 family – activates epidermal and eye ectoderm genes (motif set 15, 41, 42).  
   • PAX6 / SOX2 / SIX3-6 – canonical eye-field factors explaining the early optic-cup peak (motif sets 7, 9, 17, 34).  
   • FOX (FOXI3/FOXL2/FOXK) and DLX/ALX homeodomain factors – drive general surface-ectoderm and craniofacial epithelium programs (motif sets 2–4, 68).  
   • AP-1 / Nrf (FOS/JUN, NFE2L1/2) – stress-response and keratinocyte activation components (motif sets 22, 43, 79).  

Overall, peak cluster 22_10 marks enhancers that are first used in the optic cup and are then massively redeployed in the surface ectoderm as zebrafish embryos transition to a fully differentiated skin epithelium by 24 hpf.
]

## Cluster 22_11

[*assistant*:
Peak cluster 22_11 – concise interpretation

1. Temporal dynamics  
• Accessibility is modest at early segmentation (0-10 somites) and rises steadily, peaking at 24 hpf (≈30-somite stage).  
• The jump is especially striking in epidermis where the signal leaps from 9.8 (20 som) to 94.8 (30 som), indicating a late, switch-like activation.

2. Cell-type specificity  
Highest accessibility is seen in epithelia that give rise to motile-ciliated or secretory surface cells:  
• Epidermis/periderm – dominating signal at 30 som.  
• Hatching-gland cells – high between 5-20 som; these superficial secretory cells are also ciliated.  
• Endocrine-pancreas and general endoderm show moderate, progressive accessibility.  
Pronephros, floor-plate and neural tube derivatives display only baseline levels, underscoring epidermal preference.

3. Underlying regulatory programme  
The correlated gene set is strongly enriched for axoneme and ciliary assembly components (DYNC2H1, DNAH11/7, CCDC65, CFAP100/58, PKHD1L1, RFX-target genes, etc.), together with vesicle-trafficking and apical membrane determinants (EXOC4, RAB11FIP1, STXBP5L).  
Functional theme: formation/maturation of motile multiciliated epithelial cells and establishment of the mucociliary/secretory epidermal barrier during late segmentation-to-pharyngula stages.

4. Key transcription-factor drivers  
Motif enrichment and TF–motif mapping point to the canonical ciliogenesis module:  
• RFX family (RFX2/3/4/5/7) – central activators of axonemal gene batteries.  
• E2F4/5 (+DP partners) – cooperate with MCIDAS/GEMC1 in multiciliogenesis.  
• FOXJ1 / FOX family (FOXI/F) – master regulator of motile cilia; FOX motifs are prominent.  
• MYB and TP73 – additional MCC regulators (MYB motif present; TP53/73 family motifs enriched).  
Surface-epithelial factors that likely help specify the lineage: TFAP2 (ap2 family), GRHL1/2, TP63 and KLF5/17 clusters.

Taken together, peak cluster 22_11 marks the late-stage activation of the motile-ciliated epidermal/secretory epithelial gene programme, driven predominantly by RFX–E2F–FOXJ1 transcriptional circuitry.

## Cluster 22_13

[*assistant*:
Peak cluster 22_13 marks a late-somitogenesis, epidermis-centred regulatory program.

1. Temporal dynamics  
 • Accessibility is already detectable at the 0–10-somite stages (~10–14 hpf; values ≈4–5), rises further by 15–20 somites, and reaches a clear maximum at 30 somites (~24 hpf).  
 • The late surge indicates that the elements in this cluster become most active during the transition from late somitogenesis to early organogenesis.

2. Cell-type specificity  
 • The strongest signal is in surface ectoderm/epidermis (epidermis-30 som = ~88, >10-fold higher than the bulk of other samples).  
 • Moderate but consistent accessibility (≈5–6) is seen in other epithelial or epithelial-like derivatives (endoderm, endocrine pancreas, heart myocardium, fast muscle, vasculature), whereas neuro-mesodermal progenitors (NMP/PSM) show only basal levels.  
 • Taken together, the cluster is highly enriched in surface ectoderm, with secondary usage in several organ primordia that require epithelialisation.

3. Putative biological function  
 Associated genes are heavily enriched for:  
 • Extracellular-matrix and basement-membrane components (Col4a2/4a6/9a2/17a1b, Col18a1, Col27a1b, Lama/B, Fbn2).  
 • Cell-adhesion and junctional proteins (Cdh1/2/11, Itga10/11, Itgb4, Crb3, Prom1a).  
 • Cytoskeletal/contractility genes (Actn1/3, Myo5b, Fscn1b, Vasp, Piezo1/2).  
 • Matrix remodellers (Adamts3, Adamtsl3, Mmp-related), signalling modulators (Fgf11/12/14, Wnt‐/Tgf-auxiliary factors).  
 These signatures point to epithelial maturation, barrier formation, and ECM remodelling that accompany skin/periderm differentiation and the epithelialisation of emerging organs.

4. Key transcription-factor drivers  
Motif enrichment and TF mapping highlight several cooperating TF groups:  
 • FOX family (FOXA/C/F, FOXD3/5, FOXK) – classic pioneers for epithelial and endodermal enhancers.  
 • SOX family (SOX2/3/5/8/9/21) – ectoderm/epidermis and progenitor maintenance factors.  
 • AP-1 / ATF / NRF module (FOS, JUN, ATF3, NFE2L1/2) – couples morphogenesis with mechanical and oxidative-stress responses typical of surface epithelia.  
 • HOX–PBX–MEIS axis – patterning inputs that turn on region-specific ECM genes.  
 • Nuclear receptors (RAR/RXR, NR2F/COUP-TF, HNF4) – retinoid and metabolic control of epithelial programmes.  
 • TEAD/MEF2 and GATA factors appear as secondary contributors in muscle/endoderm sub-populations.

In summary, peak cluster 22_13 defines an enhancer set that becomes highly accessible in the epidermis at ~24 hpf and supports epithelial/ECM gene expression needed for skin barrier establishment and for epithelialisation of multiple organs, orchestrated primarily by FOX and SOX factors together with AP-1/NRF stress-responsive TFs and regional HOX-PBX inputs.

• TALE cofactors PBX1/3/4, MEIS1/2/3, PKNOX1/2 – ensure Hox DNA-binding and enhancer selection.

• E2F1/2/3/4/5/7 – transient activity accompanying final proliferation rounds.

## Cluster 23_1

[*assistant*:
Biological synopsis of Peak-cluster 23_1  

1. Temporal dynamics  
• Accessibility is already high at the earliest stage we profiled (10 hpf/0-somite; ≈400 norm. counts) and remains remarkably constant.  
• A slight uptick (≈10-15 %) is seen after 20- to 30-somite stages (≈24 hpf), indicating that the regions stay open and may even broaden as cells enter early organogenesis.  
⇒ Conclusion: this is a constitutively open cluster that is active throughout the entire 10- to 24-hpf window, with only modest late amplification.

2. Cell-type specificity  
• All >50 lineage pseudobulks show accessibility values in a narrow range (≈300-510).  
• The highest signals are in highly proliferative or metabolically active tissues—neuromesodermal progenitors (NMP), presomitic/somite mesoderm, hematopoietic-vasculature, epidermis and early muscle.  
• Very few lineages dip far below the mean (notochord/optic cup are the lower end but still >70 % of the maximum).  
⇒ Cluster 23_1 is broadly accessible; it is not lineage-restricted but slightly favours fast-cycling, progenitor-rich compartments.

3. Regulatory programme inferred  
Gene content (≫700 genes) is heavily enriched for:  
• House-keeping / basal transcription & translation: ribosomal proteins (RPL14, RPS17, EEFs, EIFs), RNA-binding proteins (HNRNPs, IGF2BP3), spliceosome and chromatin remodellers (CHD4/6/7/8, BRD4, CTCF, DNMT3B).  
• Cell-cycle and DNA-replication/repair: CCND1, E2F3, PCNA, TAFs, MCM-interacting factors.  
• Core metabolic & cytoskeletal genes: ACTB1, ACTN4, ATPases, HK1, PGAM1.  
Pathway enrichment therefore points to a “house-keeping / proliferation” module that every embryonic cell needs but is particularly demanded in rapidly dividing progenitors.

4. Key transcription-factor drivers  
Motif over-representation plus the presence of the cognate TF RNAs highlight a canonical promoter code:  
• Cell-cycle/E2F module – E2F1/2/3/4/5/7 with their dimerisation partner TFDP1; drives S-phase genes.  
• General promoter factors/NF-Y-SP-KLF – NF-Y, YY1, SP2/3, KLF family (KLF5/6/8/9/13) typical of CpG-rich constitutive promoters.  
• Chromatin-associated CpG-island regulators – KDM2B/KDM2A, CXXC1/4/5 motifs (matches strong enrichment of CxxC-binding factors).  
• CREB/ATF and ETS (ELK4, ETS2, FEV, FLI1) motifs – ubiquitous competence factors that boost basal transcription.  
• TEAD-YAP module – TEAD1/3 motifs together with robust yap1 expression; links housekeeping promoters to growth signalling.  
Altogether these TFs form the generic “basal‐proliferation” transcriptional machinery rather than a lineage-restricted patterning network.

Summary  
Peak-cluster 23_1 corresponds to a set of promoter-proximal, CpG-rich regions that stay open in virtually every embryonic cell from gastrulation through early organogenesis.  They underlie expression of core metabolic and cell-cycle genes and are controlled by ubiquitous promoter-binding TFs (E2F, NF-Y/SP/KLF, YY1, CREB/ATF, ETS, TEAD-YAP).  Its slight enrichment in progenitor domains simply reflects the higher transcriptional output of rapidly dividing cells rather than lineage-specific regulation.

Biological synopsis for peak-cluster 23_3  

1. Temporal dynamics  
• Accessibility is already detectable at gastrulation/0-somites but rises steadily with every 5-somite interval and peaks at 20–30 somites (≈ 19–24 hpf).  
• The late-peak profile (highest signals in 20- & 30-somite samples for floor-plate, notochord, tail-bud, spinal cord, PSM and somites) indicates that these regions are most active during fast trunk elongation and the onset of organogenesis.

2. Cell-type specificity  
Highest chromatin opening is seen in –  
• Axial mid-line tissues: floor plate and notochord  
• Posterior growth zone derivatives: tail-bud, neuromesodermal progenitors (NMPs), presomitic mesoderm (PSM) and forming somites/fast muscle  
• Early neural derivatives: spinal cord & hindbrain neuroepithelium, neural crest, differentiating neurons  
Accessibility is moderate or declining in more anterior / endodermal or mature organs, matching a trunk-posterior bias.

3. Likely regulatory programme  
The correlated genes and motif catalogue point to enhancers that coordinate:  
• Posterior body-axis extension and segmentation (mesp, notch/dla, fgf, wnt/β-catenin, Hox tier 1-10, tbx, msgn/mesogenin)  
• Neural-crest induction & EMT (foxd3, sox10, pax3/7, zic2/3, msx1/3, snai1a/2, zeb1/2)  
• Neural-tube dorsoventral patterning & floor-plate signalling (shh co-receptor boc, ptch2, gli2, hs6st2)  
• RA, FGF and BMP signalling integration (rara/rarg, smad3/6, sfrp5, sulf1)  
• High cell-cycle/epigenetic plasticity (lin28a, myc modulators, kdm6b, tet2/3, jarid2) typical of axial progenitors.

4. Key transcription-factor drivers (enriched motifs + expressed genes)  
Principal pioneer / lineage factors  
• Sox family – Sox2/3/5/10/11/14/19 (neuro-ectoderm & neural crest)  
• Fox family – Foxd3, Foxa/c, Foxc1/c2, Foxp1/4 (crest, mesoderm, floor plate)  
• Pax3/7, Pax6/8 (neural plate border & spinal cord)  
• Zic2/3/5, Msx1/3 (dorsal neural plate, crest)  
• Hox A/B/C tiers 1-10 (antero-posterior identity of trunk cells)  
Signal-integration / growth regulators  
• Tcf/Lef (Wnt), Tbx16/6/20 (mesoderm & segmentation), Tead/Yap1 (growth, mechanotransduction), nuclear receptors RAR/RXR/NR2F (RA feedback), Smad3 (TGF-β), E2F/FOXM1 (proliferation).  

Together, peak-cluster 23_3 marks a trunk-posterior, progenitor-rich enhancer set that becomes maximally active during late somitogenesis to co-ordinate axial elongation, segmentation and neural-crest/neural-tube patterning.
]

## Cluster 23_4

[*assistant*:
Peak-cluster 23_4 corresponds to a “core proliferation / housekeeping” regulatory module.

1. Temporal dynamics  
   • Accessibility is already high at the earliest stage we profiled (0-somite); it stays broadly elevated through 5–15 somites and begins to taper slightly as development reaches 20–30 somites and cells differentiate.  
   • The modest decline in differentiated‐neuron, epidermal and optic-cup pseudobulks (∼220–235 vs. ∼260–280) contrasts with sustained high levels in progenitor pools, indicating that the cluster is most active during the rapid-division window of early somitogenesis.

2. Cell-type specificity  
   Highest accessibility is seen in the most proliferative compartments:  
   – Neuromesodermal progenitors (NMP), tail-bud, presomitic/somite mesoderm, hematopoietic/vasculature precursors and hemangioblasts (peaks up to ~360 at 20 som).  
   – Uniform but slightly lower signal in more differentiated lineages (neurons, epidermis, optic cup, pancreas).  
   In other words, the cluster is ubiquitous but preferentially open in highly mitotic progenitor niches.

3. Regulatory programme inferred  
   Gene set: MKI67, MCM3, CDC45, UBE2C/S, CDCA8, NDC80-complex members, numerous KIFs, ribosomal proteins, translation factors, metabolic enzymes.  
   GO/Pathway implication:  
   • Cell-cycle initiation and progression (G1/S via E2F, G2/M via FOXM1/Nek2/Kif family)  
   • DNA replication, chromosome segregation, spindle organisation  
   • Core biosynthetic and energy‐metabolism processes required for cell growth and division  
   This profile matches a canonical “housekeeping + proliferation” promoter set that every dividing cell needs.

4. Key transcription-factor drivers  
   Motif enrichment points to classic cell-cycle and general-promoter regulators:  
   • E2F family (E2F1/2/3/4/5/7/8) + their dimerisation partner TFDP1 – governs G1/S gene activation.  
   • FOXM1 / FOXK / FOXO sub-family – G2/M and proliferation control.  
   • NF-Y (NFYA/NFAYL) and SP/KLF factors – ubiquitous CCAAT and GC-box promoter binders.  
   • MYB/MYBL and RUNX – additional mitotic gene regulators.  
   • YY1/CTCF – chromatin organiser motifs typical of broad promoters.  

   Together these TFs constitute the canonical programme that keeps promoters of replication, ribosome-biogenesis and metabolic genes accessible and transcriptionally competent in dividing embryonic cells.

Summary: Peak-cluster 23_4 marks promoter/enhancer regions of essential proliferation and housekeeping genes. It is open in virtually all tissues but peaks in rapidly cycling progenitors early in somitogenesis, driven chiefly by E2F/FOX/KLF-type transcription factors that orchestrate the embryonic cell-cycle machinery.
]

   • GATA family (gata4/5/6) – classic activators of cardiac lineage.  
   • TBX factors (Tbx5/20/15/18) – patterning of atrial/ventricular identity and looping.  
   • NKX homeobox (Nkx2.5/2.7) – early heart-field specification.

   • SRF/TEAD & CEBP/NRF motifs appear secondarily, consistent with cytoskeletal/ECM gene activation.

## Cluster 24_1

[*assistant*:
Peak-cluster 24_1 captures a very sharp, late-stage burst of chromatin opening that is virtually confined to the hatching-gland lineage.

1. Temporal dynamics  
   • Accessibility is flat-to-moderate (log10-norm ≈ 9) at all stages until 24 hpf (≈ 30-somite).  
   • At 30-somite stage the signal in hatching-gland cells jumps five-fold (47.0), indicating a switch-like activation that coincides with functional maturation of this secretory organ immediately before larval hatching.

2. Cell-type specificity  
   • Highest accessibility: hatching gland (30 som).  
   • Secondary but much lower signal (≈ 9–10) is broadly detectable in other endodermal derivatives (endoderm progenitors, endocrine pancreas) and some neural/neural-crest populations, suggesting these peaks are generally accessible but only maximally engaged in the mature hatching gland.

3. Regulatory programme inferred  
   • Associated-gene catalogue is enriched for endoderm / secretory-gland programmes: Foxa, Gata, Sox32/17, Nkx2-3/4 targets, secretory vesicle and ECM-remodelling genes (e.g. vcana, furina/furinb, mmp-related family members, sparc).  
   • The late burst matches the time when hatching-gland cells begin massive production and exocytosis of choriolytic enzymes that dissolve the chorion.  
   • Pathways therefore point to endoderm-specification plus terminal differentiation of an exocrine-like, protease-secreting cell type.

4. Key transcription-factor drivers (motif enrichment & mapping)  
   • Endoderm pioneers: FoxA1/2/3, FoxF1/2, FoxD3/FoxI — strong forkhead motif set.  
   • GATA family (Gata4/5/6) – required for hatching-gland specification and epithelial secretory identity.  
   • SOX32/17/19 – early endodermal competence, still enriched.  
   • NKX2 (Nkx2-3/4/5) – characteristic of pharyngeal endoderm/hatching-gland.  
   • One-cut / Pbx / Meis cofactors – typical of rostral endoderm and secretory tissue maturation.  
   • Minor but significant MEF2/TBX and HSF motifs suggest coupling to terminal secretory function and stress-responsive protein-folding load.

In sum, peak-cluster 24_1 marks the transcriptional burst that finalises hatching-gland differentiation at ~24 hpf, driven by a Forkhead-GATA-SOX-NKX core network that activates genes needed for enzyme secretion and chorion digestion.

## Cluster 24_2

[*assistant*:
Peak-cluster 24_2 corresponds to a late-segmentation/early-organogenesis vascular-lateral-plate programme that later becomes highly accessible in the differentiating endocrine pancreas.

1. Temporal dynamics  
   • Accessibility is modest at gastrulation/early segmentation (0–10 somites) but rises sharply from 15 somites onward and reaches a maximum at 24 hpf (30-somite stage).  
   • The steepest increase is seen between 20 → 30 somites, indicating that the cis-regulatory elements in this cluster are engaged during tissue morphogenesis rather than during initial lineage specification.

2. Cell-type specificity (highest pseudobulk accessibility)  
   • Lateral plate mesoderm (LPM): 12–21 a.u. across 0–20 somites – first cell type to open this cluster.  
   • Haemangioblast / haemato-vascular progenitors: 7.9 → 11.5 a.u.; and “haematopoietic-vasculature” 10–21 a.u. – consistent with nascent endothelium.  
   • Endocrine pancreas: explodes to 45.5 a.u. at 30 somites (unique spike) – suggests reuse of the same regulatory cassette in pancreatic islet precursors.  
   • Secondary but significant accessibility in endoderm and early heart myocardium (4–5 a.u.).

3. Likely biological processes regulated  
   • Vasculogenesis / angiogenic sprouting (genes: kdr, vegfc, pdgfrb, fli1a, epor, fa2h, adam12/19/ts9 for ECM remodelling).  
   • LPM-derived mesenchymal signalling and migration (pald1, tgfbr2a, lta4h, rgs7a, suox).  
   • Late re-deployment in endocrine-pancreatic epithelium, implying coordination of vascular invasion and endocrine differentiation.  
   • Enrichment of genes involved in cytoskeletal dynamics (cnn3a, vimr2, hpca) and membrane trafficking (rab3aa, rab5aa, tbc1d15) fits with active cell rearrangements during vessel/outflow tract formation and islet clustering.

4. Key transcription-factor drivers (motif enrichment & gene presence)  
   • ETS family (Fli1, Erg, Etv2/Etv4/Etv5) – canonical endothelial/haemangioblast activators; strongest motif z-scores for ETS sites.  
   • GATA factors (Gata2/3/6, Tal1 co-factor) – required for haemato-vascular specification and endocrine lineage priming.  
   • Forkhead (FoxC/FoxF/FoxG, FoxO/K) – patterning of LPM and endothelial sprouting; multiple FOX motifs highly enriched.  
   • SOXF group (Sox7/17/18) – endothelial identity; Sox motifs abundant.  
   • KLF2/6/9 & E2F cluster – proliferation and shear-stress response of emerging endothelium.  
   • HOX / PBX – positional cues within LPM; HOX-PBX motifs over-represented.  
   • In the pancreatic phase, pancreas-specific TF motifs (Pax6, Neurod/Atoh, Onecut) appear among the enriched indirect list, explaining the late endocrine-pancreas spike.

Together, peak-cluster 24_2 marks a regulatory module that is first opened in lateral-plate/haemangioblast derivatives to drive vascular and mesenchymal programmes and is later re-used in endocrine-pancreatic cells during islet organisation, under the combined control of ETS, GATA, FOX, SOXF and KLF/HOX transcription factors.
]

## Cluster 24_3

[*assistant*:
Peak-cluster 24_3 represents a late-stage, tissue-specific burst of regulatory activity that accompanies the functional maturation of somite-derived tissues and the newly forming endocrine pancreas.

1. Temporal dynamics  
   • Accessibility is modest and fairly uniform from 0- to 20-somite stages (10–20 hpf).  
   • A sharp spike appears at the 30-somite/24 hpf sample, most conspicuously in presomitic mesoderm (PSM_30 somites ≈ 27-fold above background) and in endocrine-pancreatic progenitors (≈ 44-fold).  
   → Cluster 24_3 therefore marks a late, “organogenesis-onset” regulatory wave.

2. Cell-type specificity  
   Highest values:  
   • Endocrine pancreas (β/δ progenitors) at 30 s.  
   • Posterior PSM / tail-bud mesoderm at 30 s.  
   Secondary but consistent accessibility (1.5-2.5-fold) is seen in differentiating neurons, floor-plate, heart myocardium and fast muscle, suggesting the elements are reused in several excitable/secretory lineages but peak in the two sites above.

3. Likely biological programme  
   Associated genes are heavily enriched for:  
   • Synaptic transmission & Ca²⁺ handling (RYR2, UNC13B, CACNA1ab, NTRK3b, GRIN2d, GABBR1).  
   • Cell-adhesion / axon-guidance (CNTNAP2a/3, NCAM2, CDH4, COL4/5, TENM2, SHANK3a).  
   • Muscle/contractile & ECM remodelling (MYBPC3, TBC1D1, MMP13a, FBLN5).  
   • Endocrine/secretory signalling (PLCB1, PTGIS, TG).  
   Together these point to a programme that equips maturing neurons, myofibres and endocrine cells with excitability, vesicle-release and adhesion machinery—exactly the functions that become critical at 24 hpf when motility begins and pancreatic hormone-secreting cells appear.

4. Key transcription-factor drivers (motif enrichment)  
   • bHLH neurogenic factors: NeuroD1/4/6, Atoh1/7, Olig2 – drive neuronal/endocrine differentiation.  
   • Myogenic regulators: MyoD, Myf5/6, MEF2 (MEF2A/B/C/D) – active in late PSM and nascent muscle.  
   • Homeobox patterning network: Hox-Pbx-Meis, Lhx, Dlx, Pax7/3 – confers axial and lineage identity.  
   • Sox / Fox family pioneer factors (SOX5/10/12/21, FOXD3/FORKHEAD cluster) – open chromatin and maintain multipotency.  
   • Nuclear-receptor cassette (RAR/RXR, NR2F/COUP-TF, ROR, PPAR) – links retinoid & metabolic cues to this maturation module.  
   • Circadian/clock BHLH factors (CLOCK, BHLHE40/41) hint at first establishment of rhythmic transcription in these cells.

In summary, peak-cluster 24_3 encodes the late-embryonic regulatory programme that endows posterior somite mesoderm and nascent endocrine-pancreatic cells—plus several neuron and muscle derivatives—with the molecular toolkit for excitability, secretion and tissue-specific connectivity, orchestrated by neurogenic bHLH, myogenic MEF2/MyoD, and Hox-Fox-Sox patterning factors.
]

## Cluster 24_4

[*assistant*:
Peak-cluster 24_4 marks a secretory/epithelial gene-regulatory module that turns on late in somitogenesis and is shared by the hatching-gland, endocrine-pancreas and (to a lesser extent) notochord/endoderm.

   • Accessibility is moderate at 0–5 somites (~10–12 hpf) and rises steadily thereafter.

   4. Early gut/endoderm   ~5–8 a.u. (gradually increases)  
   Most other tissues remain near baseline (~2–3 a.u.).

   Associated gene set is enriched for:

   • Hatching-gland cells that produce chorionase enzymes;  
   • Endocrine-pancreatic precursors (islet lineage);  
   • Mid-axial endoderm derivatives (notochord sheath secretion).

4. Key transcription-factor drivers (motifs enriched in the cluster)  
   • Forkhead / Fox family (FoxA1/2/3, FoxC, FoxD, FoxF) – pioneer factors for endodermal/hatching-gland epithelium.  
   • Hox / Nkx / Barx / Dlx homeobox factors (Hoxb5, Hoxc/d9-13, Nkx2-1/4/5, Barx1, Dlx2/4/5) – axial patterning and gland specification.

   • Gata4/5/6 and Sox9/10 – promote epithelial maturation and secretion.  
   • Kdm2ba motif suggests a chromatin-remodelling component that may license late activation of this programme.

Summary: peak-cluster 24_4 captures a late-somitogenesis secretory–epithelial enhancer set, maximally active in hatching-gland cells and endocrine pancreas, regulated by Fox-, Hox/Nkx-homeobox, Gata/Sox and Pdx1/Pbx factors.

## Cluster 24_6

[*assistant*:
Peak-cluster 24_6 marks a set of regulatory regions that switch on during mid-somitogenesis and are almost exclusively used by surface ectoderm / epidermal derivatives, with a late boost in the nascent endocrine pancreas.  

1. Temporal dynamics  
• Already detectable at the 0-somite stage but climbs sharply by 5–10 somites.  
• Highest accessibility between 10 and 20 somites (14-20 hpf) and remains high at 30 somites (≈24 hpf).  

2. Cell-type specificity  
Highest signals:  
• Epidermis – very strong at every time-point (log-accessibility 5.8 → 9.9).  
• A secondary spike in endocrine-pancreatic cells at 30 somites (reflecting emergence of hormone-secreting β/α cells).

3. Regulatory programme inferred  
Associated genes are typical of epithelial / secretory differentiation:  
• Structural / barrier: krt17, oclna, nectin4a, cadm1a, cdh22, lrp2a, lrp1bb, dcn, pxdn.  
• Vesicle trafficking & Ca2+-dependent exocytosis: unc13b(a), syt1a, cadps2, cacna1da, myo5aa, pi4kaa, pitpnc1b, ptgs1.  
• Cell signalling & polarity: nrg1, prkcaa, lpar2b, ndst2a, epas1a, apc/bcl9 (β-catenin module).  
Together they point to:  
• Formation/maturation of the epidermal barrier.  
• Assembly of the secretory machinery later reused by endocrine-pancreatic cells.  

4. Key transcription-factor drivers (motifs highly enriched)  
• Epidermal fate regulators: TP63 (motif set TFCP2/TPRG1), GRHL1/2, TFAP2 family.  
• SOX cluster (SOX5/9/10/21) – early ectodermal competence and keratin gene activation.  
• FOX factors (FOXA/F, FOXK, FOXC) – epithelial polarity and secretory vesicle genes.  
• RFX1/4 – ciliogenesis / junctional gene control in surface ectoderm.  
• KLF & Grainy-head motifs – reinforce barrier/keratin programme.  
• Nuclear receptors NR2F2 (COUP-TFII) & RORβ – consistent with Rorb, Nr2f2 target genes and the later endocrine signal.  
• AP-1 (FOS/JUN) and TEAD/TA co-motifs appear as secondary, supporting epithelial proliferation.  

In summary, peak-cluster 24_6 represents the epidermal/envelope gene-regulatory module that is first deployed in surface ectoderm during somitogenesis and is later reutilised by differentiating endocrine-pancreatic cells as they acquire a robust secretory apparatus.

## Cluster 24_8

[*assistant*:
Peak-cluster 24_8 corresponds to a late-gastrula/early-organogenesis “neuro-ectodermal secretory” programme that is maximally open in the hatching-gland epithelium and in the nascent retina/optic-cup, and is more modestly accessible in many differentiating neuronal populations.

1. Temporal dynamics  
• Accessibility is already detectable at the 0- to 10-somite stages (~10–14 hpf; values ~1.7–1.9).  
• It rises at 15–20 somites and reaches a sharp peak at late stages:  
  – optic_cup 20 som (23.3)  
  – hatching_gland 30 som (44.3)  
Hence the cluster is most active during 18–24 hpf (20–30-somite), i.e. the transition to early organogenesis.

2. Cell-type specificity  
Highest chromatin accessibility is seen in:  
• Hatching-gland cells (ventral yolk-syncytial ectoderm that secretes proteases for chorion rupture).  
• Optic-cup / early retinal epithelium.  
Secondary accessibility (2–2.5) is present in differentiating central- and peripheral-neurons, neural-crest derivatives, hindbrain/midbrain neuroepithelium and telencephalon, but not in mesendodermal or muscle lineages.

3. Underlying regulatory programme / biology  
Gene set points to a secretory, neuro-sensory epithelial profile:  
• Retina / photoreceptor differentiation: rcvrn2, syngap1b, gria1a/2a, grid2, nrxn1a, cadm2a, pou6f2, otx-related genes.  
• Hatching-gland markers & extracellular-matrix remodelling: bmp7b, dkk1b, mmp28, muc13a, ANPEP, DAB2.  
• Axon guidance / synaptogenesis: cntnap2a/5b, sema5a, git2b, rasgrf1/2, rims1b.  
• Secretory‐pathway / lipid-metabolism genes (acss2l, fasn, pemt, atp8b2) consistent with high vesicular output.  
Together these peaks likely control late patterning of anterior neuro-ectoderm (eye field, forebrain) and maturation of the specialised hatching-gland epithelium.

4. Key transcription-factor drivers (motifs highly enriched)  
Motif enrichment and TF–gene presence converge on:  
• Sox family: Sox2/3/14/19, Sox4/11 (neuro-ectoderm competence, retinal progenitors).  
• Fox family: Foxg1, Foxd3/Foxd5, Foxi1/2/3, Foxa1/2 (ventral forebrain, hatching-gland, secretory epithelia).  
• Hox / Pbx / Meis and Dlx/Barhl/Lhx groups (anterior–posterior neural patterning, retinal interneurons).

• Slight upward shift at the late (30-somite, 24 hpf) samples suggests global chromatin relaxation that accompanies the burst of transcription seen when embryos enter organogenesis, but no sharp time-restricted peak is observed.  →  Cluster 26_2 is constitutively open from gastrulation through 24 hpf.

2. Cell-type specificity  
• Nearly all pseudobulks lie in the same narrow range (≈190–260).  
• The very highest values are in rapidly proliferating, metabolically active tissues – tailbud, NMP/PSM, nascent somites, fast muscle, beating myocardium and hematopoietic/vascular endothelium – but neural, endodermal and epidermal populations are only marginally lower.  
→  Accessibility is essentially ubiquitous; modest enrichment in proliferative mesodermal derivatives reflects their higher global transcriptional output rather than lineage specificity.

3. Regulatory program inferred from linked genes  
• >1,000 linked transcripts encode ribosomal proteins, RNA-processing factors, core metabolic enzymes (glycolysis, TCA, oxidative phosphorylation), cell-cycle regulators, DNA-replication/repair proteins and general transcription/translation machinery.  
• Virtually no lineage-restricted marker genes are over-represented.  
→  Cluster 26_2 corresponds to CpG-rich promoters that drive basal/house-keeping functions such as energy production, macromolecular biosynthesis and cell-cycle progression.

4. Key transcription-factor inputs  
Motif enrichment is broad but the factors most compatible with a constitutive promoter program are:  
• KDM2B/CXXC module – kdm2ba motif enrichment (binds unmethylated CpG islands and recruits Pol II).  
• SP/KLF & NF-Y family (Sp1/Sp3, Klf5/6/9, NFYA/L) – classical GC-box / CCAAT-box promoter regulators.  
• E2F/DP complex (E2F1/2/3/5/7/8, TFDP1/2) – coordinates cell-cycle and DNA-replication gene expression.  
• ETS factors (Elf1/2, Gabpa, Etv family, Fli1/Ets2) – general Pol II promoter activators.  
• Forkhead/FOXK & FOXO – bind broad CpG promoters and couple metabolism to transcription.  
• Nuclear-receptor RXR/NR2F/ESRR cluster – promiscuous binding to many active promoters.

Taken together, peak-cluster 26_2 represents a ubiquitously accessible set of CpG-rich promoter elements that support core metabolic and proliferative programs in all zebrafish embryonic cells from gastrulation through early organ formation, rather than a lineage-restricted developmental regulator.

Peak-cluster 26_3 captures a “ventral-midline + early myotome” chromatin programme that is switched on at the onset of somitogenesis and is shared between the neural floor plate, nascent somites / myotome and closely related midline derivatives.

   • Gli1/2/3 ‒ main Hedgehog effectors.  
   • FoxA2 / FoxD3 / FoxO (Fox motifs) – ventral midline/floor-plate activators.  
   • Nkx2.2 / Nkx2.4 – ventral spinal cord identity.  
   • MEF2 (Mef2aa/b/c/d) and SRF – muscle gene activation.  
   • MyoD + Myf5/6 – initiate myogenic programme.  
   • TCF/LEF family – integrate canonical Wnt signalling in somites.  
   • T-box factors (Tbx6/16/20) – mesodermal segmentation.  
   • Hox/Pax/Lhx cohorts – positional and neuronal subtype codes.  
   • Nuclear receptors (ROR, RXR, NR2F/COUP-TF) – modulate differentiation timing.

In summary, cluster 26_3 represents an early, Hedgehog/Wnt-responsive regulatory module that coordinately drives ventral neural-tube (floor-plate) patterning and the emergence of neighbouring paraxial-mesoderm / myotome tissues during zebrafish somitogenesis.

## Cluster 26_7

[*assistant*:
Peak‐cluster 26_7 represents a set of broadly active, retinoid/nuclear-receptor–responsive regulatory elements that are opened very early in zebrafish development and then become progressively restricted to retinoic-acid–rich neuro-ectodermal derivatives.

1. Temporal dynamics  
• Accessibility is already high at 0-somite stage (10 hpf) in virtually all tissues (~50 AU).  
• It gradually falls through the 20–30 somite stages (22–24 hpf) in most lineages (to the high-30s).  
• An exception is the eye field/optic cup, where accessibility continues to rise, peaking at >70 AU by 30 somites, indicating prolonged activity there.

• Optic cup / eye primordium (>70 AU).  
• Posterior axial progenitors – tail-bud, NMPs, presomitic mesoderm, spinal cord (mid-40–50 AU).  
• Hox-positive hindbrain/spinal neural tube and somites.  
• Much lower signals in notochord and endoderm (≤35 AU).

3. Regulatory programme inferred  
The peak list is strongly enriched for:  
• Hox clusters (hoxa1-13, hoxb1-10, hoxc3-13, hoxd3-12) and cofactors (pbx, meis, cdx), genes that pattern the anterior-posterior (A-P) axis.  
• Retinoic-acid metabolic genes (aldh1a2, dhrs3, cyp26 family members) and many nuclear-receptor targets.  
• Hundreds of broadly expressed, early neuro-ectodermal and mesodermal regulators (pax, fox, sox, irx, tal, gata etc.).

Taken together, the cluster matches classical retinoic-acid/Hox response elements that establish A-P positional identity and, later, sustain RA-dependent programmes in the eye.

4. Key transcription-factor drivers (motif enrichment & gene set)  
• Nuclear receptors: RAR (rarga/b), RXR (rxraa/b, rxrab), COUP-TF/NR2F1-6, PPAR (ppara/pparg), Rev-erb/NR1D and ROR family – all canonical RA or lipid-sensing receptors.  
• Hox + TALE cofactors: Hoxa/b/c/d proteins together with Pbx1-4 and Meis1-3 motifs.  
• Cdx, Pax (Pax6/7/2), and Irx motifs – consistent with regionalisation of neural tube and eye.  
• Fox and Sox families – early open chromatin in pluripotent ectoderm/mesoderm.  
The presence of E2F/MEF2/TEAD motifs at lower scores fits their role in maintaining high accessibility of proliferative, housekeeping promoters that accompany the developmental programme.

In summary, cluster 26_7 demarcates a genome-wide RA/Hox regulatory module that is opened during gastrulation, patterns multiple germ layers along the A-P axis, and remains especially active in the optic cup where RA signalling stays elevated during early organogenesis.

• Activity-dependent / maturation factors – mef2 family targets, nr4a1/2, per2.  
This profile is typical of neurons that are extending long axons and beginning functional synaptogenesis.

4. Key transcription-factor drivers (enriched motifs & expressed factors)  
High-confidence regulators (motif Z-score high and gene present in cluster)  
• Neurogenic bHLH: NEUROD1/4/6, ATOH1, OLIG2 – initiate neuronal differentiation.  
• MEF2A/B/C/D – activity-dependent maturation of synapses.  
• COUP-TF / NR2F1/2 and RORα/β/γ nuclear receptors – patterning & axonal projection identity.  
• NR4A family (NR4A1, NR4A2) – immediate-early activity genes.  
• SOX cluster (SOX2/3/4/5/11/21) – maintain neuronal competence while chromatin opens.  
• FOX family members (FOXM1, FOXG1, FOXP1/2, FOXP4) – regional neuronal subtype specification and axon guidance.  
• BHLH circadian/clock factors (BHLHE22/23, CLOCK) – consistent with genes like per2.  
Together these TFs form a regulatory network that first drives neurogenesis (SOX/FOX/ATOH/NEUROD) and later supports axon growth and synaptic maturation (MEF2, NR2F/ROR/NR4A).

Summary  
Peak-cluster 31_7 represents a late-neuronal differentiation chromatin program that switches on during 20-30-somite stages, is most accessible in hindbrain, spinal-cord and general neuronal populations, and controls genes needed for axon guidance, synapse formation and early neuronal circuit activity, orchestrated by NEUROD/ATOH-type bHLH factors, MEF2 family, COUP-TF/ROR nuclear receptors and supporting SOX/FOX regulators.
