## Cluster 32_0

[*assistant*:
Peak-cluster 32_0 looks like the “default-open” promoter / CpG-island compartment of the zebrafish genome rather than a lineage-restricted enhancer set.

1. Temporal dynamics  
• Accessibility is already high at the earliest stage we profiled (0-somite, 10 hpf) and stays essentially flat (log-signal ~8.5-10) through 30-somite (24 hpf).  
• The only noticeable dips are in a few late, highly differentiated samples (epidermis-30 som, heart-30 som; signals <1), indicating that most peaks in this cluster are constitutively accessible from gastrulation through early organogenesis.

2. Cell-type specificity  
• Nearly every embryonic lineage (NMPs, PSM, neural plate/crest, endoderm, lateral plate, somitic muscle, tail-bud, etc.) shows similarly high accessibility.  
• The highest values are in rapidly-cycling or multipotent progenitors (NMPs, tail-bud, neural/enteric progenitors, endoderm) whereas fully differentiated epithelia (surface epidermis) and terminal heart muscle show the weakest signals.  
→ Cluster 32_0 is therefore “pan-embryonic” rather than lineage-specific.

3. Likely regulatory programme  
• Associated-gene list is extremely long and enriched for housekeeping and core metabolic genes (e.g. UBB, RPL/RPS, HSPs, DNA-replication, chromatin remodelers, RNA-processing, mitochondrial enzymes).  
• Gene Ontology (by inspection) points to:
  – basic transcription/RNA processing  
  – DNA replication & cell-cycle progression  
  – core metabolism (mitochondrial, lipid, amino-acid)  
  – chromatin organisation  
These are gene sets every cell needs; hence the ubiquitous accessibility pattern.

4. Key transcription-factor signatures  
Motif enrichment is broad and typical of CpG-island promoters:  
• CXXC/KDM2B – the only “direct” call in the table; Kdm2b/Cxxc1 bind unmethylated CpG islands and recruit COMPASS/SET1 – hallmarks of open promoters.  
• NF-Y, SP/KLF and YY1 families – general promoter-binding factors.  
• E2F (E2F1/2/3/4/5/7/8) – consistent with high accessibility in cycling progenitors.  
• RFX, CREB/ATF, NF-κB/Rel and ubiquitous nuclear receptors (RXR, RAR, NR2F/COUP-TF) – all common at broadly active promoters.  
• Pioneer-type FOX and SOX motifs are present but not uniquely enriched, again fitting a universal open state rather than lineage-specific control.

Overall interpretation  
Cluster 32_0 corresponds to constitutively accessible, CpG-rich promoter regions that drive housekeeping and cell-cycle genes needed by virtually every embryonic cell.  Its accessibility is established early and maintained in most lineages, tapering only in a few late, terminally differentiated tissues.  The regulatory logic is dominated by promoter-associated factors (KDM2B/CXXC, NF-Y, SP/KLF, E2F) rather than developmental, cell-type-specific TFs.

## Cluster 32_4

[*assistant*:
Peak-cluster 32_4 marks a late, lineage-restricted burst of chromatin opening that accompanies final patterning of the axial mesoderm and the eye.

• Accessibility is near basal (log-norm ~3–5) from gastrulation through 20-somite stage, then jumps 10- to 30-fold at the 30-somite stage (≈24 hpf).

• Notochord ≈ 74  
• Somites / paraxial mesoderm ≈ 74  
• Neuromesodermal progenitors (NMPs) ≈ 59  
• Background values in all other cell types remain ≈ 3–5.

Associated genes are enriched for:  
• Extracellular-matrix and basement-membrane components (Col4a1, Col15a1b, Col16a1, Col28a2b, Nid2b, Tnc, Frem2b) – consistent with sheath formation around notochord, myotome and optic cup.

• Retinoic-acid / thyroid-hormone signalling targets (Rara, Rarg, Rorb, Nr2f1/2/6, Thra/Thrb) – classical regulators of posterior axial patterning and eye morphogenesis.  
• Hox, Lhx, Dlx, Msx, Pax and Fox family genes that control rostro-caudal identity, somitogenesis and ocular field specification.

Together these signatures indicate that 32_4 comprises enhancers that:  
• respond to retinoid / thyroid and COUP-TF nuclear-receptor signalling,  
• drive ECM production and epithelial–mesenchymal remodelling in notochord and somites, and  
• promote late retinal neurogenesis / axon guidance.

4. Key transcription-factor drivers (highest motif enrichments and/or over-represented families)  
• Nuclear receptors – RAR α/β/γ, RXR α/β, COUP-TF (I/II/VI; NR2F1/2/6), ROR A/B/C, PPAR α/δ/γ, Rev-Erb (NR1D1/2) – consistent with the RA-responsive spike at 24 hpf.  
• HOX paralog groups 5-11 – establishing posterior axial identity of notochord & somites.  
• FOX factors (FoxC1/ FoxD3 / FoxF2 / FoxG1 / FoxJ1) – regulators of paraxial mesoderm morphogenesis and optic cup polarity.  
• LHX / DLX / MSX & PAX (Pax6/7, Pax3) – retinal progenitor and muscle segment patterning.  
• MEF2 & SRF motifs – myotome-specific ECM and contractile gene activation.  

In summary, peak-cluster 32_4 defines a retinoid-responsive enhancer programme that is switched on at 30-somite stage to coordinate extracellular-matrix assembly and late differentiation of axial (notochord + somite) and ocular tissues, driven by RA/RXR/COUP-TF nuclear receptors together with FOX, HOX and PAX family transcription factors.

In sum, cluster 33_4 represents a temporally-restricted, muscle-specific enhancer set that turns on during early somitogenesis, is maximally accessible in nascent fast-twitch fibres, and is governed by the classic MRF–Mef2 myogenic transcriptional network together with Tbx segmentation factors and modulators of fibre-type maturation.

## Cluster 34_0

[*assistant*:
Peak-cluster 34_0 highlights the regulatory landscape that “switches on” as zebrafish embryos leave early segmentation and enter the 10–30-somite window (≈14–24 hpf), when large numbers of trunk neural-crest and posterior axial progenitors proliferate, delaminate and migrate.

• Neural-crest derivatives – especially trunk/cranial NC at 10–30 somites (scores 15-42!).  
• Posterior tail-bud & presomitic mesoderm.  
• Early notochord and hatching-gland cells show a transient pulse.  
Somites, differentiating neurons and endoderm display only modest enrichment.  
→ The pattern fits regulatory elements shared by migratory neural-crest cells and posterior axial progenitors.

3. Regulatory programme inferred  
Associated genes are enriched for:  
• ECM & adhesion: col18a1a, col27a1b, sdc2, loxl1, serpinh2, itga8/9.  
• Rho/Rac cytoskeleton modulators: daam1a, rock2b, prex1, acap3b, sipA1.  
• Guidance / motility receptors: robo1, mcamb, igsf11.  
• TGF-β & RA signalling: tgfbr1a, tgfbr3, raraa.  
• Cell-cycle/proliferation: mybl2a, kdm5bb, tns1b, trib1.  
These functions collectively underpin epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition, extensive migration, proliferation and early chondrogenic differentiation of neural-crest mesenchyme, as well as posterior body-axis elongation.

Motif enrichment and TF–motif mapping point to a coherent NC/posterior programme:  
• SoxE/SoxB group: Sox10, Sox9, Sox8, Sox5, Sox2/3 – core neural-crest and progenitor factors.  
• Forkhead family: FoxD3, FoxC1/C2, Foxi1/3 & FoxK1/2 – EMT and migratory competence.  
• Pax3/7 & Pax2/8 – specify trunk NC and dorsal neural tube.  
• PBX/MEIS-HOX modules – confer rostro-caudal identity to migrating NC streams.  
• MSX/DLX/Barx/Lhx – early chondrogenic and craniofacial patterning regulators.  
• E2F/FOXM1 – reinforce the proliferative burst.  
• RUNX & TFAP2 family sites are present but less dominant, consistent with later skeletal lineage commitment.

In sum, peak-cluster 34_0 marks enhancers that become highly accessible in migratory neural-crest and tail-bud cells during mid-somitogenesis, orchestrating an EMT/migration-centred transcriptional programme driven by Sox–Fox–Pax–HOX networks and preparing cells for craniofacial cartilage formation and continued posterior axis extension.

1. Temporal dynamics  
   • Accessibility is very low in most stages but spikes twice:  
     – 0-somite stage (≈10 hpf): first appearance of premigratory cranial neural-crest cells.  
     – 20-somite stage (≈19–21 hpf): when neural-crest mesenchyme populates the pharyngeal arches and initiates chondrogenic differentiation.  
   • Minimal accessibility at 5–15 somites suggests a transient shutdown during neural-crest migration, with re-opening once cells reach the arches.

2. Cell-type specificity  
   • Extraordinary accessibility (37.7-fold over background at 0 somites, 23-fold at 20 somites) is confined to the pharyngeal-arches pseudobulk.  
   • All other cell types hover around basal values (~1.5), indicating that these peaks are essentially pharyngeal-arch-specific.

3. Underlying regulatory program / biology  
   • Associated genes are rich in extracellular-matrix components and remodelers (ADAMTS, COL4, FREM2, CRAT, PLPP4), signalling modulators (DKK2, VEGFC, EDNRAA, PTH1R), and chondrogenic / osteogenic regulators (RUNX3, DLX, MSX, SOX9, POSTNB).  
   • These functions converge on:  
     – Cranial neural-crest migration and condensation in the arches.  
     – Patterning along the antero-posterior (HOX code) and dorso-ventral (DLX/MSX code) axes.  
     – Onset of cartilage / bone matrix production.  
   • Thus the peak set likely marks enhancers driving early specification and later skeletal morphogenesis of the pharyngeal arches.

4. Key transcription factors inferred from motif enrichment  
   • HOX–PBX/MEIS complex (strong enrichment for multiple HOX, PBX1/3/4, MEIS1/2/3) – regional identity of individual arches.  
   • DLX, MSX, PRRX – ventral versus dorsal arch patterning.  
   • SOX10/9/6/8 and RUNX3 – neural-crest identity and chondrogenic differentiation.  
   • FOXC1/2 and TWIST family – cranial-mesenchyme migration and EMT-like behaviour.  
   • GATA3/6 and TCF/LEF sites – integration of endodermal/mesodermal signalling and Wnt input.

Taken together, peak cluster 35_13 represents a pharyngeal-arch enhancer module that turns on in cranial neural-crest cells as soon as they are specified, re-opens when they settle in the arches, and is orchestrated by a HOX/PBX-DLX/MSX-SOX regulatory cassette to drive craniofacial skeletal patterning.
]

## Cluster 35_14

[*assistant*:
Peak cluster 35_14 represents a large set of cis-elements that are preferentially bound by Sox-family transcription factors and are opened very early in the posterior progenitor field of the embryo.

1. Temporal dynamics  
   • Accessibility is maximal at the earliest sampled stage (0-somite / 10 hpf).  
     – Tail-bud_0 somites shows an exceptional signal (≈38-fold above background).  
   • Signal gradually tapers through somitogenesis but a modest “second bump” is seen around 20 somites (especially in tail-bud and migrating neural-crest derivatives).  
   • By 30 somites the cluster is largely closed in most lineages.

2. Cell-type specificity  
   Highest accessibility ranks:  
   1. Tail-bud progenitors / axial stem cells (NMPs, posterior PSM).  
   2. Neural-crest lineages (neural_crest 15–20 somites, enteric-neurons 20 somites).  
   3. Early neuro-epithelial cells and generic neural progenitors (neural / differentiating_neurons).  
   4. Secondary signal in diverse mesodermal progenitors (lateral plate, early heart, endoderm) but at lower amplitude.

3. Underlying regulatory programme  
   The associated gene list is strongly enriched for:  
   • Sox-controlled neural/neural-crest factors (sox2/3/14/19, sox5/6/8/9/10, sox21).  
   • Posterior patterning and body-axis extension genes (multiple hox clusters, tbx, fox, nkx, cdx).  
   • Progenitor-maintenance and chromatin remodelers (kdm2, lin28, dnmt1, cxxc genes).  
   Together these point to a programme that keeps posterior axial stem cells and early neural-crest progenitors in a multipotent, rapidly proliferating state while the body axis elongates. When these cells exit the tail-bud and start lineage commitment (≈15–20 somites) the same elements are reused in neural-crest derivatives.

4. Key transcription-factor drivers  
   Motif enrichment is dominated by Sox consensus sites; the only direct factor listed for this cluster is kdm2ba (consistent with an open, CpG-rich environment) but the indirect list pinpoints:  
   • SoxB1 group: Sox2, Sox3, Sox19a/b – neural/embryonic stem-like state.  
   • SoxD/E group: Sox5/6 and Sox8/9/10 – chondro-neural-crest and glial trajectories.  
   • Sox21/14 – neural differentiation modulators.  
   Supporting but lower-rank motifs: Fox (Foxd3, Foxf2), Tcf/Lef (Wnt response), E2F (cell-cycle) – all typical of proliferative posterior progenitors.

In summary, peak cluster 35_14 demarcates Sox-responsive enhancers that are highly open in the tail-bud at gastrulation/early somitogenesis, remain accessible in posterior axial stem cells, and are redeployed during neural-crest formation and early neurogenesis, orchestrated chiefly by Sox family TFs with assistance from Fox and Wnt/Tcf factors.
]

## Cluster 35_15

[*assistant*:
Peak-cluster 35_15 marks the chromatin programme that drives posterior body-axis extension and early segmentation.

1. Temporal dynamics  
   • Accessibility is already high at 0-somite stage, rises further through 5-10 somites (peak values in PSM_10 som, Spinal cord_10 som ≈ 8.5–8.8) and starts to wane after 20 somites.  
   • By 30 somites (≈ 24 hpf) accessibility collapses in most posterior compartments (e.g. NMP_30 som ≈ 1, PSM_30 som ≈ 6.7), indicating shutdown once trunk elongation is complete.

2. Cell-type specificity (highest accessibility)  
   • Presomitic mesoderm (PSM)   
   • Neuromesodermal progenitors (NMPs) / tail-bud  
   • Posterior spinal cord & generic “spinal_cord” pseudobulks  
   • Early forming fast-muscle / nascent somites (moderate)  
   Low in endodermal, epidermal, pancreatic, optic and most anterior neural lineages.

3. Implied biological programme  
   • Posterior axial progenitor maintenance and proliferation (Lin28a, Cdx, Wnt/Tcf targets).  
   • Hox-controlled antero-posterior patterning and rostro-caudal identity specification.  
   • Segmentation clock & somite maturation (Notch/Rbpj, Mesp-like, Tbx16).  
   • Transition of NMPs into paraxial mesoderm vs. spinal-cord neural fate.  
   • Concomitant ECM/cytoskeletal remodelling needed for convergent-extension and myotome assembly (Adamts, Col, Itg, Fhl2, Tln1).

4. Key transcription-factor drivers (motif enrichment + expressed genes)  
   • Sox-family pioneer factors – Sox2/3/19, Sox10/11 – maintain bipotent NMP chromatin.  
   • T-box factors – Ta/Brachyury, Tbx16, Tbx6/4 – convey Wnt/Fgf signals to mesodermal genes.  
   • Cdx & posterior Hox (Hoxb4-b9, Hoxc8-c13, Hoxd9-d13) – encode axial‐level identity.  
   • Tcf/Lef (Wnt effectors) & Rbpj (Notch) – segmentation-clock signalling.  
   • Fox (Foxd3/5, Foxa/f) – integration of neural vs. mesodermal programmes.  
   • E2F / Mcm motifs – high proliferation of tail-bud progenitors.  

Together, cluster 35_15 delineates a transient, posteriorly-restricted regulatory module that orchestrates the switch from multipotent tail-bud progenitors to presomitic mesoderm and nascent spinal cord during 10–22 hpf, and is silenced once elongation ceases.
]
